awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: High-frequency ultrasound technology for the detection of micro and nano porosity, shale softening and anisotropy of materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a novel ultrasound technology to characterize deep geological media for energy exploration and waste disposal. The incorporation of high frequency ultrasound technology is investigated to non-destructively obtain the rock porosities. By developing an in situ device to determine the porosity of a rock matrix, the team seeks to determine the extent of softening that occurs due to fracking. This technology has potential for use in a wide variety of infrastructure applications. By developing a new method to determine the porosity of rock matrices and the in-situ rock permeabilities directly in the field and at a smaller scale (in the nano and micro ranges), this research team seeks to increase the productivity of companies that require (in)direct seismic data acquisition (e.g., Drilling Engineers, Wireline Engineers, Seismic Acquisition Engineers, Seismic Processing Engineers, Petro-Physicists and Geophysicists).

This I-Corps project is based on the development of high-frequency ultrasound technology. Ultrasound technology is a non-destructive technology that generates mechanical waves from ultrasound transducers.  The technique has been increasingly utilized in studying the lithology of the Earth. The in-situ use of ultrasound coupled with a new modelling capabilities, may provide a quicker, more environmentally friendly, and inexpensive alternative to field investigation. The new technology will be used ot determine the porosity of rock matricies as well as the possible softening that occurs due to fracking. The wave velocity can be determined by transmitting high-frequency ultrasound waves (>200Hz) through the rock specimens and relating the measured velocity to micro- and nano-scale voids. Once the wave velocity function has been determined, the team will transmit a range of higher frequencies whose wavelengths are closer to the size or micro- and nano-scale voids in the rock matrix. The attenuation, time, and velocity of the waves at higher frequencies will be compared to determine the porosity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project was to support the development of high-frequency ultrasound technology for the detection of micro and nano porosity, shale softening and anisotropy of materials. Ultrasound technology is a non-destructive technology that generates mechanical waves from ultrasound transducers. The technique has been increasingly utilized in studying the lithology of the Earth. The in-situ use of ultrasound coupled with a new modelling capability, may provide a quicker, more environmentally friendly, and inexpensive alternative to field investigation for oil and gas exploration. The new technology will be used to determine the porosity of rock matrices as well as the possible softening of shale that occurs due to injection of water based fluids to facilitate hydraulic. fracturing. The wave velocity can be determined by transmitting high-frequency ultrasound waves (>200Hz) through the rock specimens and relating the measured velocity to micro- and nano-scale voids. Once the wave velocity function has been determined, the team will transmit a range of higher frequencies whose wavelengths are closer to the size or micro- and nano-scale voids in the rock matrix. The attenuation, time, and velocity of the waves at higher frequencies will be compared to determine the porosity. 

 

The research idea for this project was based on prior NSF project (CMMI#1634857, $476,577.00, 9/2016-8/2021), "Remediation of Contaminated Sediments with Ultrasound and Ozone Nano-bubbles," PI Jay N. Meegoda, which  investigated an innovative in-situ approach to remediate contaminated sediments.  To evaluate the commercial potential and gain valuable market insights for the development of the ultrasonic technology for  the detection of micro and nano porosity, shale softening and anisotropy of materials, the team participated in the NSF I-Corps Team Program. The goal of the I-Corps project was to use the customer discovery and preparation of a business model canvas to find the market fit for technology and identity the early adaptor through customer discovery interviews to develop ultrasound technology for the detection of micro and nano porosity, shale softening and anisotropy of materials. 

The team identified and initiated interviews with the stakeholders of several customer segments in oil and gas industry to learn about their problems and challenges to identify the market demand and find the market fit for ultrasound technology. We propose to incorporate this technology into drilling rigs or in vertical/horizonal wells in deep geological media, so that one will be able to determine the micro/nano porosity of the interested layer, and also the possibility of softening when the fluid moves through flow paths. This information will be used in the designs to determine the optimal fracture spacing. Thus, with in-situ porosity data over a wide range of micro/nano void sizes, it is possible establish a more versatile method of determining the variation of micro/nano voids with the interaction of fracking fluids. This research team will explore the porosity as a function of wave velocity allowing companies to better understand a wider spectrum of in-situ porosity of rocks and their potential for softening. The wave velocity can be determined by transmitting high-frequency ultrasound waves (>200Hz).

In total team conducted 125 interviews with various stakeholders in the industry and gained insight into the market demand. During the interviews with the stakeholder of the oil and gas industry, we identified a niche for the technology. The stakeholders in this customer segment face challenges with optimizing the oil and gas production. Hence they are looking for new and innovative solutions. 

The team has already filed a provisional patent for this novel non-destructive technology for earth subsurface characterization. The team is planning to apply for federal grants such as the DOE, NSF Partnership for Innovation program, SBIR programs, and approach energy and commercial companies/firms to pursue some non-Federal capital commitments, including personal investment, venture capital investment, and intent to collaborate.

Modified by: Jay N Meegoda
